questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about COPD?
A. Increased TLC
B. Increased VC
C. Decreased FEV1/FVC ratio
D. Increased FRC
questions.solution:
This is a normal spirometry showing the various lung volumes. If a time element is added with forced expiration to it, FEV1 and FVC can also be calculated, as given below.


In obstructive lung disease, FEV1 is disproportionately reduced when compared to FVC, hence the ratio is reduced. In restrictive lung disease, the FEV1 tends to be fast, but quickly approaches the FVC, hence the ratio will be high, as FVC is disproportionately reduced over FEV1.

In obstructive lung disease, residual volume will be high and FRC will be high, vital capacity, ERV and IRV will be low. All the lung volumes will be reduced in restrictive disorders.

In COPD pulmonary hyperinflation leads to increase in TLC. FRC is also elevated to loss of elastic recoil and hyperinflation. RV is also increased.

questions.text:
Which of the following is smoking related ILD?
a. Respiratory bronchitis
b. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
c. Pulmonary Langerhans histiocytosis
d. Desquamative interstitial pneumonitis
questions.solution:
Respiratory Bronchiolitis with ILD, Desquamative Interstitial Pneumonia and Pulmonary Langerhan Cell Histiocytosis are related to prior or current tobacco use. The former 2 have the features of Idiopathic Interstitial pneumonia, while PLCH is unique in clinical features, histology and imaging.

PLCH occurs in relatively young patients. They are either current or ex smokers. 50% of patients improve with smoking cessation. In the rest 50% there is activating mutation of BRAF, similar to neoplastic process and in them the disease will progress necessitating lung transplant. Histologically it is characterized by accumulation of Langerhans cells and eosinophils in the airways and alveoli, leading to scarring. Radiologically it is characterized by formation of cysts. Langerhans cells are positive for S100, CD1a and CD 207 and are negative for CD68.

DIP and RB ILD tend to occur in elderly patients.

DIP is characterized by the accumulation of large macrophages in the air spaces, called smokers macrophages. Some of the macrophages contain lamellar bodies made of surfactant. Excellent response to smoking cessation and steroids. Diffuse GGO is seen radiologically.

RB ILD is characterized by accumulation of smokers macrophages in the peribronchial spaces in the first and second order bronchus. Radiologically characterized by the presence of central and peripheral bronchial thickening and rarely GGO. The presence of honey combing indicates a worst prognosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Parathyroid adenoma causes primary hyperparathyroidism.

Secondary hyperparathyroidism occurs when the blood calcium level falls which stimulates the parathyroid glands to secrete more PTH in an attempt to increase the Calcium levels. Eg: Vitamin D def

In CKD, FGF 23 increases which inhibits 1α hydroxylase which leads to vitamin D deficiency and secondary hyperparathyroidism.

In Li intake, the PTH secretion curve is shifted to the right. I.e higher Ca; levels are required to stimulate PTH secretion.

In primary hyperparathyroidism, there is autonomic growth of parathyroid glands. In secondary hyperparathyroidism there is an adaptive response of the parathyroid glands and is typically reversible once the stimulus is removed.

questions.text: Drug that promotes bone formation among the following?
questions.solution:
Among the agents used in the management of osteoporosis, the only agent with an action on osteoblast is Teriparatide, which when given daily causes a true increase in bone mass and apparent restoration of bone architecture. It acts via the Wnt signaling.

Abaloparatide, is a PTHrP analogue. It binds to acts via the PTH 1 receptor. There are two confirmations for the receptor, R0 and RG. It binds to similar affinity with the RG confirmation and with less affinity to R0 and hence it has similar bone formation and lesser bone resorption action compared to PTH.

questions.text: Value of investigations in osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Investigations in Osteoporosis:

  1. Bone mass measurement: DEXA scan is used for bone density measurement. Lumbar spine and hip are the sites that are commonly preferred. T scores compare the result obtained for an individual with race and sex matched young adult population. Z scores compare individual result to age and sex matched reference population. Values are between -2.5 to +2.5. a T score <2.5 in the femur or lumbar vertebrae is diagnostic of osteoporosis. A score between -1 and -2.5 is low bone mineral density. >50 % fractures occur in low bone mineral density

The absolute fracture risk assessment is made by calculating the FRAX score. It takes into account age, sex, height, weight, fracture history, history of fracture in parents, steroid use, history of rheumatoid arthritis, other secondary causes and bone density in femur. It calculated the 10 year fracture risk.

Vertebral fracture assessment (VFA) can be done using DEXA scan by using lateral view of thoracic or lumbar spine. Since most of the vertebral fracture are asymptomatic, it can be detected using vertebral abnormality, age, gender and BMD.

  1. CT, USG MRI and high resolution quantitative CT are research tools. HRQCT uses peripheral bones like tibia.
  2. Tetracycline labeling and bone biopsy allows for evaluation of bone remodeling and evaluation of metabolic bone disease. It has become obsolete with the advent of non-invasive modalities.
  3. Biochemical markers of bone formation and resorption.

These are mainly used for assessing response to treatment. With the advent of antiresorptive agents, the bone resorption declines earlier than bone formation. Hence the measurement of markers of bone resorption before initiating treatment and repeated 2-6 months after initiating treatment is batter assessment of treatment response than density of bone. These are indicated for treatment with Bisphosphonates, Denosumab and estrogen and are not used for weaker agents like calcitonin and raloxifene. Teriparatide is the agent which stimulates osteoblasts. Response to treatment can be assessed by bone formation markers like PINP(most sensitive) or osteocalcin.

questions.text: A female presented with increased TSH and very low T4. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A low T4 and a high TSH suggest the diagnosis of primary hypothyroidism.

The commonest cause of primary hypothyroidism is Autoimmune.

questions.text: As filtrate flows through PCT, the concentration of all of the following decreases except
questions.solution: The major absorption of glucose, bicarbonate and amino acids occur at the PCT. Chloride is reabsorbed in the loop of henle.

questions.text: Macula densa is formed by all except?
questions.solution:
At the point where the afferent arteriole enters the glomerulus and the efferent arteriole leaves, the tubule of the nephron touches the arterioles of the glomerulus from which it arose. This point marks the beginning of the DCT. There is a modified epithelium in the DCT here and is known as the macula densa.

The media of the afferent arteriole contains the JG cells which contain membrane bound secretory granules. These along with the Lacis cells (agranular cells) which are found in the junction between the afferent and efferent arteriole, produce renin.

The JG cells, the macula densa and the Lacis cells constitute the JG apparatus.

questions.text:
Membranous nephropathy is associated with-
A. HIV
B. SLE
C. CLL
D. Hepatitis B
High anion gap acidosis with low bicarbonate levels is seen in all the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
Early renal failure is associated with hyperchloremic acidosis. But in late CKD, there is no further decrease in HCO3.

DKA, salicylate poisoning and lactic acidosis cause high anion gap acidosis. Late uremia also causes high anion gap acidosis.

So the possible option is B

questions.text: Iritis is seen in all except
questions.solution:
OCULAR MANIFESTATIONS OF CONNECTIVE TISSUE DISEASES:

SLE: keratoconjunctivitis sicca is the commonest ocular manifestation. It occurs with or without secondary Sjogrens syndrome. SLE retinopathy can be detected on ophthalmoscopic examination as retinal hemorrhages, vasculitic appearing lesions, cotton wool spots and hard exudates. The pathology is either immune complex mediated vasculopathy or micro thrombotic events. Retinal abnormalities correlate with CNS lupus, lupus nephritis and APS.

Episcleritis and scleritis occurs in SLE, but uveitis is extremely rare.

Glucocorticoids used for the treatment of SLE causes posterior sub capsular cataract, elevated IOP and central serous maculopathy and HCQ can cause maculopathy.

Rheumatoid Arthritis: Keratoconjunctivitis sicca. Episcleritis(painless), scleritis(painful), scleromalacia perforans, chronic blepharitis, peripheral ulcerative keratitis, iritis and uveitis can also occur.

Behcet's disease: occurs in 40-60% cases. Anterior or posterior uveitis, panuveitis bilateral, iridocyclitis, keratitis, episcleritis, vitritis, retinal vein occlusion and optic neuritis.

Ankylosing spondylitis: Acute anterior uveitis or iridocyclitis is the most common ocular manifestation occurring in 25-30% cases. More seen with B27 positive patients than negative patients.

Reactive arthritis: conjunctivitis, anterior uveitis(iritis). Rare: scleritis, pars palnitis, iridocyclitis

IBD associated arthritis: Scleritis and episcleritis follows disease activity. Uveitis may or may not parallel disease activity.

questions.text:
A 25 year old female develops cyanosis of digits when hand is put in cold water followed by redness. Which of the following is responsible for this manifestation?
a. Scleroderma
b. Migraine
c. Cryoglobulinemia
d. Hyperthyroidism
questions.solution:
The question deals with Raynaud's phenomenon: Raynaud's phenomenon is episodic vasoconstriction affecting the tops of fingers and toes and sometimes of the tip of nose and earlobes. Attack typically begins with pallor(vasoconstriction), cyanosis(ischemia) and hyperemia(reperfusion).

Primary Raynaud's phenomenon: Raynaud's disease. Occurs in the absence of any underlying condition. It is just an exaggerated vasomotor response to cold.

Secondary Raynaud's phenomenon: occurs in association with Systemic sclerosis, Sjogren syndrome, PAN, Takayasu Arteritis, Antisynthetase syndrome, acromegaly, progressive diaphyseal dysplasia, drugs like beta blockers, cisplatin, bleiomycin, ergot alkaloids, bromocriptine, Clonidine, cocaine, Dextramphetamine, methylphenidate, phentermine, interferons

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about the drugs used in gout?
a. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid secretion
b. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint
c. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways
d. Aspirin is used as it is most powerful NSAID
questions.solution:
Aspirin is not used in gout as it decreases urate secretion. Aspirin has to be given in large doses for anti-inflammatory action. There are more potent anti-inflammatory drugs than aspirin.

A, B and C are correct.

questions.text:
Woman with morning stiffness which gradually resolves over one hour. Which is correct about the treatment and findings?
a. NSAIDS improve symptoms and have disease modifying activity
b. Absence of erosion on x-ray rules out diagnosis
c. Raised ESR and CRP
d. HLA DR4 is related to prognosis
questions.solution: The question deals with RA. NSAIDS are not disease modifying agents. They are analgesic and anti-inflammatory. ESR and CRP may be raised in RA. RA has a strong HLA association to DR locus. RA classically causes erosive arthritis. But plain X ray may not be always showing erosions. It can be viewed using MRI or ultrasound.

questions.text: Patient presented with massive abdominal swelling. Paracentesis fluid was sent for lab analysis and came out to be having serum protein to be 3g/dl and ascitic fluid protein to be 1g/dl. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This question deals with the concept of SAAG. If the SAAG is <1.1, portal hypertension can be easily ruled out.

The causes are TB peritonitis, Carcinomatous peritonitis, pancreatitis and nephrotic syndrome.

A high SAAG with low ascitic fluid protein means the sinusoids are scarred and cant secrete protein and is seen in Cirrhosis, Late Budd chiari and massive liver mets.

High SAAG with high protein in ascitic fluid is seen in cardiac failure, early budd chiari, sinusoidal obstruction, IVC obstruction

Ascitic fluid LDH is measured if a secondary peritonitis is suspected. Secondary peritonitis is characterized by ascitic fluid glucose of < 50mg/dl, ascitic fluid LDH > serum LDH and poly bacterial culture of ascitic fluid.

Ascitic fluid amylase >1000 indicates pancreatitis.

With a cut off of 35-40u/L, ADA has a > 90% sensitivity in diagnosis of TB peritonitis.

questions.text: Patient comes with palpitations to ER. His pulse-180 bpm and BP -70/50 mm of hg. ECG shows narrow qrs complex tachycardia with regular heart rate. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution: The patient in the given question is having a regular narrow complex tachycardia with a blood pressure of <90mmHg systolic, which is considered as unstable hemodynamics, which should be managed by cardioversion.

questions.text: A 40 year old patient presents with vomiting episodes followed by severe abdominal pain, blood in stool and prostration. His bp IS 90/50 mm hg and pulse is 180 bpm with irregularly irregular rhythm. Per abdomen finding is unremarkable except for absent bowel sounds. Past medical history of CAD. Which is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
A severe abdominal pain with hypotension and AF, with minimal abdominal findings is the most common presentation in acute mesenteric ischemia(95%).

Acute mesenteric ischemia can be embolic or thrombotic.

Embolic mesenteric ischemia is suspected in elderly patients with risk factors for embolism like AF, infective endocarditis, previous embolic events.

Thrombotic acute mesenteric ischemia is suspected in a patient with underlying thrombotic atherosclerotic disease.

AMI is a surgical emergency. In a suspected patient the gold standard investigation is CT angiography with 1mm cuts. If an acute embolic occlusion is detected, surgical exploration with resection of the ischemic bowel. A transverse arteriotomy is made and the thrombus should be removed. The return of blood flow is assessed clinically by noting the return of hyperemia to the bowel or by applying duplex at the antimesentric border. Second look surgery should be done in case of questionable bowel viability.

The gut is supplied by the Coeliac trunk, SMA and IMA.

There is extensive collateral formation along the gut wall. These collaterals meet at the splenic flexure and the sigmoid colon, where they are prone fro ischemia, known as the Griffiths and the Sudecks point respectively. These are the commonest sites of colonic ischemia.

Acute mesenteric ischemia may be, arterio occlusive, non occlusive or venous thrombosis. 50% of AMI is due to occlusion of mid to distal SMA. Embolic etiology includes AF, valvular heart disease, IE, recent cardiac catheterization, recent MI, soft atherosclerotic plaque. In >75% cases the source of emboli comes from the heart and lodges in the SMA

Non occlusive ischemia is seen in acute hemodynamic instability as seen in hypovolemic shock or drugs causing vasoconstriction. It is the most important and prevalent GI complications following a cardiovascular surgery.

Venous thrombosis is seen in hypercoagulable states either congenital or acquired.

questions.text:
Sequence after p wave?
A. A wave
B. 1st heart sound
C. Rapid filling of ventricles
D. T wave
questions.solution: P wave corresponds to the electrocardiographic atrial systole, which corresponds to the a wave of JVP. Atrial systole(reduced filling phase) is followed by ventricular systole, marked by the closure of the AV valves or the first heart sound. This is followed by the ventricular ejection(QRS) into the aorta and pulmonary artery. This is followed by the ventricular diastole(T wave), which is marked by the closure of the semilunar valves 2nd heart sound, the AV valves are already closed. During this phase the atria gets filled. When the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial, the AV valves open and the passive filling or the rapid filling phase occurs. Followed by atrial systole.

questions.text: Patient came to the hospital within 3 hrs of onset of chest pain. ECG revealed ST depression in Anterior chest leads and t wave inversion. She is best managed by?
questions.solution:
The initial treatment of these consist of providing pain relief. The main anti ischemic treatments given are nitrates, Beta blockers and bed rest.

Anti thrombotic treatment remains the corner stone of treatment. This

includes antiplatelets and anticoagulants.

Antiplatelets: in patients with NSTEMI or UA two antiplatelets should be used. Cyclooxygenase inhibitor aspirin should be given in a dose of at least 162 mg followed by 75-100mg/day. A P2Y12 inhibitor should be added, if there is no high risk for bleeding. Clopdogrel 600mg loading followed by 75mg/day. Other P2Y12 inhibitors are Prasugrel, 60mg loading followed by 10 mg per day. It is preferred for those in whom an invasive strategy is planned. It is contra indicated in the previous stroke, TIA. It is associated with a high bleeding risk. Ticagrelor is reversible. 180mg loading dose followed by 90mg twice daily is used. Beneficial for both invasive as well as conservative management. Cangrelor is an IV P2Y12 inhibitor which is rapid and IV. It is recommended as an adjunct in patients undergoing PCI to reduce post-procedure MI, recurrent revascularization and stent thrombosis.

Anti coagulants: unfractionated heparin, LMWH, fondaparinux and Bivaluridin are the anticoagulants used.

After giving the initial treatment, the patient has to be risk stratified to determine if the patient has to be taken up for an early PCI VS conservative management. In high risk patients, those with multiple risk factors, ECG changes and positive troponin, an early invasive strategy should be followed which is definitely beneficial than a conservative strategy. In low risk patients, early invasive or conservative approach has similar outcomes. In a low risk patient, a PCI is carried out if the CT Coronoary angio shows occlusion, positive stress test or raising biomarkers.

In the question, the patient's pain is subsiding with sublingual nitrates, but has recurrent angina and multiple risk factors, the ideal treatment would be an early invasive treatment. But since that is not there LMWH or heparin is the next best.

So the best treatment would be PCI.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are used for absence seizures?
questions.solution: Valproate, ethosuximide and Lamotrigine are the drugs used in typical absence seizures.

questions.text: Which of the following exacerbates myasthenia?
questions.solution:
This table shows the drugs that interact in M gravis. Among the antibiotics, quinolones and macrolides exacerbate myasthenia. Among the local anesthetics, procaine and lignocaine in large quantities also worsen myasthenia. Magnesium is an ion that worsens myasthenia.

Among the given options Digene is an antacid that contains MgOH and Mg aluminum silicate. So the most appropriate answer is Digene.

questions.text: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with new onset chest pain, without any previous history of angina/MI. The drug with which of the following mechanisms of action might have caused this presentation?
questions.solution: Triptans are a group of anti migraine drugs that cause vasoconstriction. So they have the propensity to precipitate angina.

questions.text: All of the following are subcortical dementia except?
questions.solution: Wilsons disease, Parkinsons disease and Huntingtons disease affect the subcortical structures like basal ganglia and have dementia as an associated feature. Picks disease is a cause for cortical dementia.

choices.text: Poor prognosis compared to classical Hl

questions.text: All of the following are true about NLPHL except
questions.solution: NLPHL is now considered to be a distinct entity from HL. The neoplastic cells in NLPHL are called the HRS like cells or L&H cells or popcorn cells. They lack CD15 and CD 30 unlike RS cells. They are positive for CD19, 20, 45, 79a and BCL2. They run a chronic indolent course. EBV is implicated in HL and not NLPHL.

questions.text: Jak2 mutation is most commonly associated with?
questions.solution: 95% polycythemia rubra vera and 50% of Essential thrombosis and myelofibrosis have JAK 2 mutation.

questions.text: A child was brought to the ER with a lesion on the forearm as seen. As a surgery resident, you decide to excise the lesion in emergency ot. Which of the following investigations will test for the entire coagulation?
questions.solution: Thromboelastography can be used for guiding intra operative transfusion. But it cant be employed in other disorders of bleeding and thrombosis. It has some role in venom induced coagulopathy

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will have the least chance of dry tap alone?
questions.solution: MDS has the least chance of dry tap.

questions.text: The following cause pancytopenia except:
questions.solution: Among the given options APML is the least possible cause.

questions.text:
A patient with cervical lymphadenopathy has t(11;14) positive. Which of the following markers should be done to confirm the diagnosis?
A. CD10
B. CD200
C. SOX11
D. CYCD1
questions.solution:
t(11,14), is seen in Mantle cell lymphoma, which leads to over-expression of Cyclin D. SOX11 encodes for SRY related HMG box family of transcription factors. Mantle cell lymphomas that express SOX11 are more indolent and require only observation. They present with circulating disease and splenomegaly, but with no lymphadenopathy and very low Ki67.

Blastic variant of mantle cell lymphoma has high Ki67 and is more aggressive with a median survival of 18 months.

choices.text: Steroids followed by Anti Parasitic drug

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is correct regarding management in this case?
questions.solution:
The arrow in the MRI shows viable cysts in the brain parenchyma.

It is characteristic of neurocysticercosis.

The arrow in the MRI shows viable cysts in the brain parenchyma.

It is characteristic of neurocysticercosis.

The clinical manifestations of neurocysticercosis is mainly seizures. It can cause obstructive hydrocephalus by blocking CSF flow. Patients can present with features of raised ICP like head ache and papilledema. They can also lodge in the sub arachnoid space causing chronic meningitis, arachnoiditis, communicating hydrocephalus, hemorrhages or strokes.

TREATMENT:

Intestinal disease is treated with a single dose Praziquantal or Niclosamide.

Neurocysticercosis: Antiepileptics should be started. Albendazole 15mg/kg for 8-28 days with or without Praziquantal 50-100mg/kg/day for 15-30 days. Combination is preferred for people with more than 2 lesions. Lesions in the subarachnoid space need prolonged treatment and here Methotrexate or anti TNF agents can be used as steroid sparing agents. High dose steroids are needed since antiparasitic drugs will elicit an inflammatory response. Steroids will enhance the first pass effect of Praziquantal and it should be co administered with Cimetidine. For multiple lesions and diffuse cerebral edema, steroids are the initial mainstay and antiparasitic drugs should be avoided. Surgery is the main treatment for ocular disease. Spinal disease may worsen with antiparasitic lesions and may lead to irreversible damage. Either medical or surgical treatment can be used for spinal disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in the management of COVID 19?
questions.solution: The agents that are approved for the treatment of COVID 19 are Dexamethasone, Remdesivir with or without the JAK 1 and 2 inhibitor Baricitinib, Tocilizumab (IL6 monoclonal antibody) and SARS CoV 2 specific monoclonal antibody.

questions.text: Most common lung injury in COVID 19 infection?
questions.solution:
The primary pulmonary pathology in COVID 19 is excessive clotting, activation of inflammation and endothelial injury.

Fox SE, Akmatbekov A, Harbert JL, et al.. Pulmonary and cardiac pathology in African American patients with COVID-19: an autopsy series from New Orleans. Lancet Respir Med 2020; 8:681-686.

choices.text: Call for help -check carotid pulse and breathing -give CPR
Leave the person and go looking for a friend and come back to the scene

questions.text: A doctor goes for a morning walk and finds a person unconscious in the park. Which is correct about CPR?
questions.solution:
According to BLS guidelines, the following steps are to be taken:

  1. Scene safety should be checked.
  2. Check for the responsiveness of the patient by shaking the patient
  3. Shout for help from the surroundings
  4. Activate AED
  5. Look for carotid pulse and breathing
  6. Start CPR if no pulse and breathing-30 compressions and 2 rescue breaths.
  7. Continue cycles until AED arrives.
